title: Take a ride on Manchester's Second City Crossing
text:
Take a ride on Manchester's Second City Crossing Faster, more frequent, reliable trams could be headed this way Share By Charlotte Cox Katie Butler 22:05, 21 FEB 2017 Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Preview of the Second City Crossing Share this video Get daily   Could   
Footage has revealed Metrolink’s new Second City Crossing in action for the first time. 
Ahead of its launch to the public on Sunday, the M.E.N had a sneak preview of the service through the heart of Manchester. 
The 1.3km route, which was three years in construction, runs from Deansgate-Castlefield to a major new stop at St Peter’s Square, along Cross Street to stops at Exchange Square and Victoria station. Read More Don't throw silica gel packets away - they're not as useless as you think ... 
Part of a big city transport project which includes new bus lanes, cycle routes and train tracks, it will allow more trams to pass through the centre of Manchester. The aim is to free up space on the network, boost frequency and improve reliability. 
It also means Manchester Airport services will run all the way into the city centre, at first to Deansgate-Castlefield, then Victoria later this year. Peter Cushing (TFGM Metrolink Director). (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
Services that currently terminate at Deansgate-Castlefield and Exchange Square will continue across the city centre to Shaw and Crompton and East Didsbury. 
It’s the last piece in the £1.5bn expansion jigsaw, which started wth the line to East Didsbury in 2009, and continued with new lines to MediaCityUK, Rochdale via Oldham, Ashton and Manchester Airport. Metrolink is now the biggest light rail system in the UK. Read More Hundreds of angry fans stuck in queues outside Etihad Stadium for first part of Manchester City vs Monaco game 
Peter Cushing, Metrolink director for Transport for Greater Manchester, said: “The route really gives us the capacity to run more trams through the city centre but also gives us resilience because if we ever have an issue, for example, in Piccadilly Gardens, we can run things along the Second City Crossing rather than have to wait to resolve that issue to be able to run everything. So what that means is that we have much more resilience in the system and we will be able to run things with a lot more surety and a lot more reliability.” 
The first phase of the Second City Crossing opened from Victoria through to a new stop at Exchange Square in December 2015. L to R Peter Cushing (TFGM Metrolink Director), Lord Mayor of Manchester Carl Austin-Behan and Councilor Andrew Fender (TFGM Committee). (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
This allowed a six-minute daytime service to run between Shaw and Crompton, Oldham and Exchange Square from Monday to Saturdays. 
Coun Andrew Fender, chairman of the TfGM Committee, helped develop the Metrolink concept in 1982. He said it had been a remarkable journey, and paid tribute to all those involved. 
Sir Richard Leese, leader of Manchester City Council, said the route would make travel easier while taking in some of the city’s most iconic landmarks. 
He added: “The new line highlights the journey of our city, how much the city has changed in such a short space of time, and represents a major milestone in Manchester’s continuing development and growth.” 
From Sunday 26 February, the following services will run: 
· Altrincham – Bury (via Market Street) 
· Altrincham – Etihad Campus
